newsitem.title: UK: Gold slides, seen probing support at $345.
newsitem.headline: Gold slides, seen probing support at $345.

text.p: Gold struggled to keep composed above $345 an ounce on Tuesday but sentiment was loosening and dealers expected support to come under critical test.
"Pressure does seem to be on the downside. People are disappointed that the market hasn't performed better given the sell-off in the equities," said one London dealer.
"I think quite possibly the market is looking to test that level ($345). Whether it holds it I don't know," he added.
Bullion fixed lower at $345.60 an ounce versus Monday's $346.75 and New York's close of $346.00/$346.50.
It has been under pressure since Friday following strong U.S. inflation data pointing to interest rate hikes, which increases the opportunity cost of holding gold against the dollar.
Further clues on inflation will be provided on Tuesday with U.S. March Consumer Price Index (CPI) due at 1230 GMT.
Opinion differed however on whether $345 would act as a buffer, or trigger sell stops and force bullion down to $340.
"The $345 area is critical support, but I think it will bounce," said technical analyst Karen Jones of Credit Suisse First Boston.
Others, though, including analyst Martin Squires of broker Rudolf Wolff believed that gold had lower to go.
"A descending triangle is developing...suggesting further downside movements can be expected," he said, referring to New York's April Comex gold futures contract.
Brokers GNI thought hot money could pour into gold from currency markets if the dollar began to look a bit toppy.

"In the very short term, there could be a lot of dollar longs looking to take profit, and there could easily be a quick bounce in the stock market which may make gold ripe for a brief bounce as well. But do not expect it to be more than a few dollars or to last very long," it said in a daily market commentary.
Palladium fell from grace after last week's spike above $160, and was quoted unchanged on the day at $151.25/$152.25.
But the market was still prone to sharp fluctuations while it awaited news from Russia, the world's biggest exporter, on delayed PGM (platinum group metals) sale contracts to Japan.
No word has yet emerged after last week's comments by a Russian official that a long-awaited government decree would be signed this week, enabling exports to begin some time in May.
Silver was also flat at 4.72/$4.74, but in the absence of buying interest the market could suffer further liquidation by disappointed longs and probe the $4.65 low, analysts said.
